info.name: PostsAPI
info.description:
#### This documentation presents to you a RESTful API that mimmicks the posts functionality of Facebook. 

## Functional Requirements
This API supports the following actions:
- Registration & login with email & password
- Authentication with JWT
- Send an email to a user after registration
- Password reset
- Publish a post
- Fetch a post
- Delete a post
- Edit a post
- Like & undo post like ??
- Reply to a post
> Note: *A user is also be able to upload images to posts and replies*

request.description:
#### An Endpoint to register a new user. 

After registration, the user gets a confirmation email. Please use a valid email when registering.

The Payload needed to register are:
- Username
- Email
- Password

response.name: POST /auth/local/register

request.description:
#### Send an email to a user after registration.

After registering. You need to confirm your email so we are sure you are the owner of the account. 
A link will be send to your email. 

The link sent to your email has a confirmation token, this token verifies your email.

For testing purposes, please copy the confirmation token from your email and replace it with the Token variable in the URL to verify your account. 

Once the request is made to verify your token, you will receive a JWT token in the response body.

On the Postman collection attached to this documentation, The JWT token is automatically stored in the postman's environmental variable and you can continue making authenticated requests.

response.name: GET /auth/email-confirmation?confirmation={TOKEN}

request.description:
### Authentication with JWT

You can also Login to your account as a user with this endpoint, which generates a new JWT token for use, in subsequent API calls.

For testing on postman, this JWT token is automatically stored in the postman's environmental variable and you can continue making authenticated requests.

If a user forgets their password, you could receive their registered email via this endpoint. The email should be supplied as shown below.

Once the request has been made, An email will be sent to the reqistered email address with a password reset code

### Password reset

Once you get he password reset code from your email, please copy it and add it to the payload to be sent to this route, with your new password and a password confirmation field.

For testing on postman, a JWT token will be re-issued as part of the response which is automatically stored in the postman's environmental variable and you can continue making authenticated requests.

response.name: POST /auth/reset-password

request.description: This is an endpoint to get the details of the currently authenticated user. This is good for building profile pages.

response.name: GET /users/me
response.body:
{
    "id": 7,
    "username": "abbeyseto",
    "email": "adenleabbey@hotmail.com",
    "provider": "local",
    "confirmed": true,
    "blocked": null,
    "role": {
        "id": 1,
        "name": "Authenticated",

        "type": "authenticated"
    },
    "created_at": "2021-05-31T19:33:15.454Z",
    "updated_at": "2021-06-02T12:50:40.270Z",
    "liked_posts": 2
}

item.name: Posts

request.description:
### Fetch a post

This endpoint gets all the post from all users. by default this returns a maximum of 100 objects from the server. A more efficient way is to use the endpoint in the next section below.

response.name: GET /posts

request.description:
This is a more efficient version of the /post end route. 

By setting a limit, it improves seen and the results are paginated with a response that contains a link to fetch the next set of results or go back to the previous set of results.

The limit you set will be maintained all through the paginated navigations.

response.name: GET /posts?_limit=5

request.description: This is an endpoint to get an individual single post

response.name: GET /posts/{id}

request.description:
### Publish a post

You can create a new post using this endpoint.

This endpoint accepts **multipart/form-data** if you are uploading an image with the post or **contentType/json** if you are only creating a text based post.

>Note: JSON only payloads should be sent with a key of **data**, and the images should be sent with a key of **files**.

response.name: POST /posts

request.description:
### Edit a post

You can update a post using this endpoint.

This endpoint accepts multipart/form-data if you are updating an image with the post or contentType/json if you are only updating a text based post.

Note: JSON only payloads should be sent with a key of data, and the images should be sent with a key of files.

response.name: PUT /posts/{id}

request.description:
### Delete a post

You can delete a post using this endpoint.

This endpoint accepts the post ID.

>**Cascade Delete Note**: when a post is deleted, replies to such post are also deleted with all attachments that belong to it.

response.name: DELETE /posts/{id}

request.description:
### Like & undo post like ??

This endpoint allows you like a post.

It accepts the post's id and the id of the user liking the post and a json boolean payload

> **NOTE:**This endpoint does **not** allow you like a single post multiple times.

response.name: PUT /posts/{id}/likes{user_id}

item.description:
This is a resource path for getting posts. A user needs to be authenticated first before being able to fetch resources from this route. 

For unauthenticated users, a forbidden error is sent as a response

item.name: Replies

request.description: This endpoint fetches all the replies of a post by passing the post id
This endpoint gets a single reply to a post

response.name: GET /replies/{id}

request.description:
This endpoint accepts multipart/form-data if you are uploading an image with the replies to a post or contentType/json if you are only creating a text based replies.

The *user* field in the JSON payload is the id of the user posting the reply to a post.

> Note: JSON only payloads should be sent with a key of data, and the images should be sent with a key of files.

response.name: POST /replies

request.description:
This endpoint accepts multipart/form-data if you are updating an image with the replies to a post or contentType/json if you are only creating a text based replies.

> Note: JSON only payloads should be sent with a key of data, and the images should be sent with a key of files.

response.name: PUT /replies/{id}

request.description: This endpoint deletes a single reply

response.name: DELETE /replies/{id}

item.description:
This is the resource for sending replies to a post.

Users are able to send replies to a post mostly using the post id
